title: Tools
text:
I built this tool to provide professional-grade analysis for runners. It focuses on structure, discipline, and recovery‚Äîmetrics that standard platforms often overlook.
Features: * Norwegian Intervals: Analyze pace and heart rate discipline for structured work. * Ghost Battle: Compare two run files to visualize where you gained or lost time. * Recovery Check: strict verification of heart rate caps.






Note



Privacy Note: Your data is processed entirely in memory and is not stored permanently.

title: Speed Work
text:
Speed work is not just for elite athletes. It improves efficiency and makes your ‚Äúeasy‚Äù pace feel even easier.
However, we do not train until we vomit. We train to stimulate, not annihilate.

title: Speed Work
text:
The Classics

Strides: 4-6 x 20 second accelerations at the end of an easy run.
Hill Sprints: Short, max effort bursts up a steep hill (great for power, low impact risk).

title: Speed Work
text:
Norwegian Singles (Double Threshold)
This method, popularized by the Ingebrigtsen brothers, has revolutionized endurance training. While elites do this twice a day, we can adapt the principles for normal life.

The Concept
Instead of running continuous hard tempos (e.g., 20 mins hard), you break the work into short intervals with very short rest. * The Goal: Keep your lactate levels controlled. You should not be gasping for air. You should feel like you could go faster, but you don‚Äôt. * The Magic: You get more volume at ‚Äúthreshold‚Äù pace without the fatigue of a continuous run.


The Workout
Try this ‚ÄúNorwegian‚Äù style session: 1. Warm up: 10-15 mins easy. 2. The Work: 10 x 3 minutes at Threshold Pace. * Recovery: Only 60 seconds (standing or walking). * Intensity: 7/10. Comfortably hard. NOT sprint pace. 3. Cool down: 10 mins easy.






TipWhy it works



By taking a 60-second break every 3 minutes, you clear the lactate before it builds up. This allows you to do 30 minutes of quality work, whereas a continuous run might force you to stop after 15 minutes.

title: Primal Endurance
text:
‚ÄúHealth leads to performance.‚Äù

Primal Endurance aims to be a ground-breaking guide that revolutionizes the way we approach endurance training. This book was the original inspiration for changing my training methodology after a few years of constant injuries.






TipKey Takeaways



üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Stay Slow: Focus on aerobic development via MAF training.
üí™ Do Strength Work: Essential for durability.
ü¶∂ Go Barefoot: Drills to recover foot strength.

title: Primal Endurance
text:
‚ÄúHealth leads to performance.‚Äù

Primal Endurance aims to be a ground-breaking guide that revolutionizes the way we approach endurance training. This book was the original inspiration for changing my training methodology after a few years of constant injuries.






TipKey Takeaways



üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Stay Slow: Focus on aerobic development via MAF training.
üí™ Do Strength Work: Essential for durability.
ü¶∂ Go Barefoot: Drills to recover foot strength.

title: Primal Endurance
text:
My Review
Authored by Mark Sisson and Brad Kearns, the book presents a comprehensive blueprint for achieving peak performance while embracing the primal principles of ancestral health.
Sisson and Kearns skilfully marry their expertise in endurance training with the ancestral wisdom of our hunter-gatherer ancestors. The result is a holistic approach that prioritizes intuitive training, emphasizing the importance of aerobic development through MAF training and metabolic efficiency over traditionally high-stress, ‚Äúchronic cardio‚Äù routines.

Accessibility & Science
The authors provide a wealth of practical advice, backed by scientific research, to guide readers on the journey to becoming fat-adapted athletes.
One of the book‚Äôs standout features is its accessibility. They break down complex concepts into easily digestible information, making it suitable for both seasoned athletes and those new to the world of endurance sports. The inclusion of real-life success stories adds a motivational layer to the narrative.


The Barefoot Component
It is also great to see barefoot shoes and drills being encouraged. We evolved to be barefoot and whilst our feet are too weak from years of cushioning and at risk from modern paths, there is no reason some barefoot walking can‚Äôt be used to improve technique and stave off injury.


Conclusion
‚ÄúPrimal Endurance‚Äù doesn‚Äôt just stop at training methodologies; it also explores the importance of nutrition, sleep, and stress management in achieving optimal performance. The emphasis on a holistic lifestyle approach ensures that readers walk away with a comprehensive understanding of how to thrive in all aspects of life.

title: Welcome to My Blog
text:
This is my first blog post.
I will use this space to share race reports, training updates, and random thoughts on the running world.

title: Welcome to My Blog

Why I am blogging
Because running is more than just miles; it‚Äôs about the journey. I wanted a method to try and get me to start journalling and keeping a track of things and lets see if this works.

title: Other Methods & Resources
text: A collection of training methods, recovery protocols, and resources that are essential to the holistic runner.

title: Other Methods & Resources
text:
Cross Training
When I say cross training, I am referring to everything from walking and rucking to the elliptical, swimming, and cycling.
See Mental Training to fully appreciate how much this kind of training can help you.
Key Benefits: * Cardio & Recovery: If you are finding the running volume too high but want to improve, cross training increases aerobic load while reducing impact. * Active Recovery: There is a growing body of evidence showing that a gentle walk is more beneficial for recovery than sitting on the sofa. * The ‚ÄúRuck‚Äù Hack: Going for a recovery walk? Add a backpack with a little weight. It increases strength and cardio load. So long as you stay under your desired heart rate, it is awesome training (even better on hills).

title: Other Methods & Resources
text:
Recovery Protocols

1. Massage
Massage has numerous reported benefits. The odd session with a sports masseuse is a good investment, and for day-to-day use, a massage gun can really help.
Reported Benefits: * Blood Flow: Flushes waste products (like lactate) and delivers oxygen/nutrients for repair. * Flexibility: Breaks up adhesions and releases tight muscles, improving range of motion. * Mental State: Reduces cortisol (stress hormone) and improves sleep quality.






WarningImportant Considerations




Timing: Some athletes prefer massage before competition to relax, others after for recovery.
Caution: A deep sports massage is not advised shortly before an all-out performance (it can leave legs feeling ‚Äúheavy‚Äù).





2. Compression
I have had mixed results myself, but there are many reported benefits for compression clothing. * The Theory: It supports blood flow and reduces muscle oscillation. * The Reality: Even if the physical benefit is marginal, the Expectation Effect (see Mental Training) makes it worth trying. It is unlikely to hinder recovery.


3. Breathing
For a deep dive, read Breath: The New Science of a Lost Art.

Nasal Breathing: Try to adopt nasal breathing during most of the day and even on walks.
Tools: Devices like the AiroFit have limited evidence, but if you can get one second-hand, it can be a useful tool for respiratory strength.



4. Bio-Hacks

Standing Desks: Essential for flexibility. If you sit for 8 hours, your hip flexors shorten, which ruins your running gait. Stand where you can.
Power Poses: Based on the TED Talk by Amy Cuddy. Performing ‚Äúpower poses‚Äù (standing tall, arms open) can increase testosterone and improve performance. Consider integrating this into your pre-race routine.

title: Other Methods & Resources
text:
My Library
I am constantly reading and researching. If you only read three books this year, make it these:

The Big Book of Endurance Training - Phil Maffetone
Born to Run - Christopher McDougall
Why We Sleep - Matthew Walker

title: Other Methods & Resources
text:
References

Massage & Recovery: Rapaport et al., 2010 (NCBI)
Power Poses: Amy Cuddy TED Talk

title: Mental Training
text:
Mental training is an untapped performance enhancer for almost everyone. Athletes like Keely Hodgkinson have attributed 90% of their performance to the mental side of things.
If it works for Olympians, it is worth working on.
I 100% recommend the book The Confident Mind by Dr.¬†Nate Zinsser. The following strategies are heavily influenced by his work on practical sports psychology.

title: Mental Training
text:
The 7 Key Steps






1. Set Ambitious Goals Goals should be scary. Once set, work consistently towards believing that you can achieve them.
2. Use Affirmations Come up with ‚ÄúI am‚Äù statements that you can read, think of throughout the day, or record and listen to while running. (See below for examples).
3. Focus on the Positives * Past: Focus on races and training that went well. * Present: In a session, focus on the single rep that felt good. * Future: Focus on what you can control.
4. Create a Confidence Board Combine your mental cues into a single view. See my example here.
5. Visualization Using all your senses, imagine yourself achieving your next goal. Be as detailed as possible.
6. Reframe the Day If you are having a bad day, simply change your mind and decide to have a good day.
7. Manage Expectations Understand the power of the ‚ÄúExpectation Effect‚Äù (see below) for both training and racing.

title: Mental Training
text:
Affirmations
These don‚Äôt require cardio, so you can do them even when your legs are dead.






TipMy Daily Affirmations




‚ÄúI am fit, I am fast, I am strong.‚Äù
‚ÄúI am light, I am recovered, I feel good.‚Äù
‚ÄúI am confident. I have self-belief. I run well in all conditions.‚Äù
‚ÄúI am the healthiest and most consistent I can be.‚Äù
‚ÄúI do the little things well. My strength training powers my running.‚Äù
‚ÄúI focus on the controllables and do not worry about what I cannot control.‚Äù
‚ÄúI am unstoppable. I am capable of great things.‚Äù

title: Mental Training
text:
Visualization
The goal is to create a script for you to listen to or read out loud that details you crushing your next goal. You should use as much detail and as many senses as possible‚Äîsmells, sights, the feel of your clothes, your thought patterns.
Here is a script based on my local parkrun winter route:

‚ÄúI arrive at the event in good time‚Ä¶ I feel confident, recovered and have belief that my training will power me through.
I perform my strides and warm up drills, noticing how my legs and arms feel strong and powerful. My shoes feel springy. I arrive back at the start line and move to the front. I undertake my CBA routine and prepare my convictions: ‚ÄòIt is my time to shine, I have done the work, today is my day.‚Äô
As the RD says go, I get up to speed quickly. I am confident and do not let others‚Äô performances deter me. My breathing becomes deep and the breeze starts to cool my skin‚Ä¶ I pass through the 1km point onto the long back straight‚Ä¶ I can feel my legs are still feeling strong‚Ä¶
I drive over the bridge, through the underpass and onto the final straight. I kick going past the final bench and bolt through the finishing funnel.
I have just had the run of my life. I feel elated and exhausted and in disbelief of my time. I smile as I head home to share the news.‚Äù

title: Mental Training
text:
The Expectation Effect
Research by Alia Crum shows the true link between the brain and the body. She demonstrated that simply believing a food was filling made it more filling, and cleaners who were taught that cleaning is good exercise actually became fitter.
Apply this to running: * If you believe caffeine gives you a boost, it will have a larger impact. * If you believe running slow makes you fast, you will likely see faster improvements. * Researching your training methods increases your belief in them, which physically enhances their effectiveness.

Recommended Viewing
 Change your mindset, change the game: Dr.¬†Alia Crum at TEDxTraverseCity
 The Expectation Effect: David Robson at TEDx


Recommended Books

The Confident Mind by Dr.¬†Nate Zinsser
The Expectation Effect by David Robson
Beyond Grit by Cindra Kamphoff

title: Be Happy & Healthy
text:
First and foremost, I want you to enjoy your life. Running should be a source of happiness, not stress. My golden rule is simple: Fit running around your life, do not fit your life around your running.
Most people struggle to sustain habits that require constant discipline. Think about how hard it is to force yourself to lose weight or run in conditions you hate. If you rely on willpower alone, you will eventually burn out.
Instead, we focus on enjoyment. Prioritize your sleep, your recovery, and your family (well, assuming you enjoy your family!). When you enjoy the process, consistency happens automatically.

title: Be Happy & Healthy
text:
First and foremost, I want you to enjoy your life. Running should be a source of happiness, not stress. My golden rule is simple: Fit running around your life, do not fit your life around your running.
Most people struggle to sustain habits that require constant discipline. Think about how hard it is to force yourself to lose weight or run in conditions you hate. If you rely on willpower alone, you will eventually burn out.
Instead, we focus on enjoyment. Prioritize your sleep, your recovery, and your family (well, assuming you enjoy your family!). When you enjoy the process, consistency happens automatically.

title: Be Happy & Healthy
text:
Prioritise Sleep
Sleep is the single most effective performance enhancer available. If you have a choice between an extra hour of sleep or setting an early alarm to squeeze in a run, choose the sleep.
Here are the key protocols I recommend for maximizing recovery:

Mind the Gap: Stop eating at least 3 hours before bed. Digestion interferes with deep sleep.
Training Timing: Try to leave a 3-hour gap between exercise and sleep. I know this is difficult with evening running clubs, but do your best to wind down.
Light Control: Use blue light filters on your devices or wear blue light blocking glasses in the evening.
Environment: Keep your bedroom cool, dark, and comfortable.
The ‚ÄúLight Sleeper‚Äù Hack: If you wake up easily, try sound blockers. I personally use ear buds playing an audiobook with a calm narrator. It blocks out noise and stops my brain from racing.

title: Be Happy & Healthy
text:
Integrating Family & Life
Finding time to train is often the biggest hurdle. The solution is not to ignore your family, but to integrate them into your movement.
Everything depends on your personal circumstances, but here is how I have made it work:

1. The ‚ÄúSocial‚Äù Run
Run with a slower partner, or if you have kids, let them ride a scooter or bike alongside you while you run. You get your training done, and you get quality time together.


2. The ‚ÄúErrand‚Äù Run
Turn chores into training. Run to the shops, run the dog, or run to commute. It kills two birds with one stone.


3. The ‚ÄúSplit‚Äù Run
Don‚Äôt be afraid to break a long run into bite-sized chunks.

My Experience: I have previously replaced a single long run with four mini-runs:

2 miles on the morning school run
2 miles walking the dog at lunch
2 miles on the afternoon school run
3 miles with my wife in the evening

Was a single 9-mile run better physiologically? Probably. But I couldn‚Äôt fit a continuous 90 minutes into that day. 9 miles broken up is infinitely better than 0 miles perfectly planned.

title: About Me
text:
I am a qualified running coach, but my real education comes from experience.
Since 2014, I have spent years researching and experimenting to find out what truly works. I aim to train in a way that prioritises health to achieve performance, whereas many traditional plans chase performance at the expense of health.
I have researched running, nutrition, mental training, strength training, and went down every rabbit hole I can find. I remain open-minded, largely due to my own transformative experience with diet and lifestyle.

title: About Me
text:
My Qualifications
I hold the official coaching certifications from England Athletics:

LiRF (Leader in Running Fitness)
CiRF (Coach in Running Fitness)

title: About Me
text:
My Journey
If I can do it, anyone can.
My journey into running started from a place of struggle. I used to weigh 20 stone and relied on a walking stick due to a crippling foot condition (Ledderhose disease).
I reversed my health through the very methods I now teach‚Äînutrition, barefoot movement, and patience.
Read more about my journey with Plantar Fibroma

title: Barefoot Running
text:
ImportantMedical Disclaimer



This content is based on my experience and research. If you have any injuries at any point, you should consult with a medical professional before continuing.
Barefoot walking and running (or using minimalist footwear) has numerous health benefits. It is not just a trend; it is about restoring natural function.

title: Barefoot Running
text:
Improved Foot Strength & Function
1. Enhanced Proprioception Walking and running barefoot stimulate the sensory receptors in the feet, improving proprioception (awareness of your body‚Äôs position in space). This leads to better balance, coordination, and a reduced risk of falls, especially in older adults.
2. Strengthened Foot Muscles Without the ‚Äúcrutch‚Äù of supportive shoes, your foot muscles are forced to work harder to stabilize the foot and absorb impact. This leads to increased strength and improved mechanical function.
3. Reduced Risk of Injury While counterintuitive, studies suggest that barefoot running may reduce the risk of certain injuries‚Äîsuch as stress fractures and plantar fasciitis‚Äîby promoting a more natural gait and reducing high-impact heel strikes.

title: Barefoot Running
text:
Posture & Gait

Natural Gait: Minimalist movement encourages a midfoot or forefoot strike, which reduces stress on the joints and improves efficiency.
Improved Posture: By strengthening the foot and ankle complex, barefoot movement contributes to better overall posture, reducing strain on the knees, hips, and back.

title: Barefoot Running
text:
Other Potential Benefits

Reduced Stress: Stimulating the nervous system through the soles of the feet may promote relaxation and reduce anxiety.
Improved Circulation: The mechanical stimulation of the feet may help improve blood flow.
Earthing (Grounding): Walking barefoot on the earth‚Äôs surface allows for the transfer of electrons from the earth to the body. Proponents believe this can reduce inflammation and improve sleep.








WarningImportant Considerations



1. Transition Gradually This is the most critical rule. If you are new to barefoot movement, your calves and Achilles are likely tight and weak. Start with laughably short distances and gradually increase duration over months, not weeks.
2. Choose Appropriate Surfaces Avoid rough or hazardous surfaces initially. Opt for soft, natural surfaces like grass or sand until your skin and muscles adapt.
3. Listen to Your Body If you experience pain, stop immediately. Rest is part of the process.
4. Consult a Professional If you have existing foot concerns, consult a qualified podiatrist (preferably one who understands functional movement) before starting.

title: Barefoot Running
text:
Recommended Reading

Born to Run by Christopher McDougall
Born to Run 2 by Christopher McDougall

title: Barefoot Running
text:
References

Harvard: Biomechanics of Foot Strikes
Red Bull: Benefits of Barefoot Running
Healthline: Walking Barefoot
MIT: Staying Grounded

title: Personal Coaching
text: I believe that everyone is unique. You deserve a dynamic training guide, not a rigid spreadsheet.

title: Personal Coaching
text:
My Philosophy
Most training plans fail because life gets in the way. A static PDF cannot adjust when you get sick, work gets stressful, or you just feel tired.
I work differently. I limit myself to a small number of runners at a time so I can provide true personalization. We will build a flexible training guide together. We remain dynamic‚Äîadjusting the structure as your life changes‚Äîso you can focus on the running while I focus on the planning.

Who I Coach
Whether your goal is getting off the couch, smashing a parkrun PB, or completing your first Half Marathon, I can help.

Important Note: I put your health first. I do not coach for distances longer than a Half Marathon (21km), as I believe the training volume required for ultra-endurance events is often contrary to long-term health.

title: Personal Coaching
text:
How It Works

1. The Onboarding
Before we run a single mile, we need to ensure we are a good match. * The Portfolio: You will complete a ‚ÄúGetting to Know You‚Äù portfolio covering your history, injuries, and wildest goals. * The Consultation: We will have a virtual or face-to-face meeting to dig into the details. * The Strategy: We align your target races with a realistic roadmap.


2. The Training
Humans are complex systems. Running performance is not just about miles; it is about health. * Holistic Guidance: I provide advice on strength training, mental resilience, technique, and nutrition (including low-carb/keto adaptations if that is your goal). * Regular Feedback: We stay in touch regularly. You share how you feel; I adjust the guide.

title: Personal Coaching
text:
What Is Included
When you sign up, you get a fully comprehensive package:

Initial Consultation: Deep dive into fitness, aspirations, and lifestyle constraints.
Health Audit: Review of injury history and relevant health markers.
Personalized Guide: A dynamic training structure built for you.
Feedback Loop: Regular support via email and scheduled calls.
Resource Library: Access to my advice on nutrition, mental performance, and strength conditioning.

title: Personal Coaching
text:
Investment






NoteSetup & Onboarding



¬£50 (One-off) Includes initial portfolio analysis, health history review, and strategy consultation.








TipMonthly Coaching



¬£45 / month Includes dynamic planning, regular feedback, and ongoing support.








Important1-on-1 Sessions



¬£50 / hour Optional face-to-face coaching for technique analysis or in-person support.


Get in Touch to Start

title: Gary Manley Running
text:
I am a running coach with a unique philosophy. I believe that running should enhance your life, not dominate it. Whether you are chasing a parkrun PB or training for your first Ultra, the biology remains the same.
Read My Philosophy

title: Gary Manley Running
text:
I am a running coach with a unique philosophy. I believe that running should enhance your life, not dominate it. Whether you are chasing a parkrun PB or training for your first Ultra, the biology remains the same.
Read My Philosophy

title: The MAF Method
text:
Running shouldn‚Äôt dictate your life, and you shouldn‚Äôt always be stressing about a plan. I prefer to call them schedules or guidelines.
Listen to your body. Enjoy running as part of a healthy life.

title: The MAF Method
text:
The Core Philosophy
A key feature of my training is running slow. To go fast, we must first build the engine to go far without stress.
In an ideal world, you will use a chest-strap heart rate monitor, but a wrist-based one or even ‚Äúrunning by feel‚Äù can work if you are honest with yourself.






NoteThe 180 Formula (MAF)



The basic approach is to perform your cardio at 180 minus your age.

Example: If you are 40 years old, most of your running should be below 140 beats per minute (bpm).
The Limit: 140 bpm is the maximum, not the average.

To start with, this can be frustrating. It will likely include walking, especially uphill. I suggest a Base Phase where almost all your running is done at this heart rate. It builds a massive aerobic base without the cortisol stress of high-intensity training.

title: The MAF Method
text:
The 80/20 Rule
Another popular philosophy I use is 80/20 Running.






TipThe Balance




80% of your training should be very easy (like the MAF pace above).
20% of your training is speedwork.

Why this matters: If you run 30 miles a week and run a hard parkrun (3 miles), you have done your 10% speedwork right there. If you do the rest of your runs ‚Äúkind of hard,‚Äù you are training in the grey zone‚Äîtoo hard to recover, too easy to get fast.


I favour a conservative approach: start at 100/0 (all easy), then move to 90/10, and finally 80/20 only when your body is ready.

title: The MAF Method
text:
Additional Resources

Essential Viewing
 Run for your life! At a comfortable pace, and not too far: James O‚ÄôKeefe at TEDx


Recommended Reading

Book: The Big Book of Endurance Training and Racing (Phil Maffetone)
Article: Want Speed? Slow Down
Article: Overcoming Frustrations with MAF
Guide: What is 80/20 Running?

title: Nutrition & Fasting
text:
WarningDisclaimer



I am not a qualified nutritionist. The following is based on 10 years of personal research and investigation since being obese myself. Depending on your dedication, gut health, and metabolic flexibility, there are many approaches you can take. Take from this what you want.

title: Nutrition & Fasting
text:
The Hierarchy of Diet
To start with, the priority is running slow. If you then want to ease into healthier eating, that is the next step. You don‚Äôt need to do everything at once.
Here is the progression I recommend, depending on how ‚Äústrict‚Äù you want to be:

Level 1: The Basics

Remove or minimize alcohol.
Remove processed garbage (cakes, biscuits, sweets, etc.).

Level 2: The ‚ÄúPaleo‚Äù Approach

Reduce foods that were not available 10,000 years ago.
Cut out: Pasta, rice, flour, bread.
Eat: Meat, dairy, fruit, and vegetables.

Level 3: The Keto Diet

Remove vegetables grown below ground (potatoes, carrots, etc.).
Limit berries and high-sugar fruits.








TipGut Health



If you are struggling with digestion or inflammation, I find that Kefir really helps where other methods haven‚Äôt.

title: Nutrition & Fasting
text:
The Eating Schedule (Fasting)
‚ÄúDiet‚Äù is what you eat; ‚ÄúFasting‚Äù is when you eat.
This approach takes advantage of the fact that humans naturally fast overnight. Extending this window allows insulin to drop and fat cells to be mobilized. This pairs perfectly with slow running (MAF).
Work by scientists like Tim Noakes has shown that becoming ‚Äúfat-adapted‚Äù increases the energy you can derive from body fat during intense exercise, significantly reducing the chance of ‚Äúbonking‚Äù (running out of energy).

My Protocols

The Morning Window: Don‚Äôt eat for 2-3 hours after waking up.
Fasted Training: Do some morning runs before eating anything.

Reference: I regularly do parkrun fasted (approx. 21 hours without food).

The Evening Gap: Do not eat for at least 3 hours before bed.



Advanced Adaptation
If you take well to fat adaptation, you can push this further. It is routine for me to:

Run 10 miles first thing in the morning.
Not eat until lunchtime.
Fit in strength training or cross-training later.
Eat only one meal a day (OMAD) or within a 1-hour window.


Note: This level of fasting is for metabolically flexible runners. Don‚Äôt force it if you feel dizzy or weak.

title: Nutrition & Fasting
text:
Additional Resources
Here are the key resources that have shaped my understanding of nutrition and performance.

Dr.¬†Tim Noakes & Low Carb

The Noakes Foundation: Challenging the dogma around carbohydrates and performance.
Public Health Collaboration UK: A charity dedicated to improving public health through lifestyle changes (Real Food/Low Carb).
Diet Doctor: The world‚Äôs largest low-carb site with visual guides on what to eat.



Gut Health & Fasting

Mark‚Äôs Daily Apple: The definitive guide to the ‚ÄúPrimal‚Äù (Paleo) lifestyle.
Dr.¬†Jason Fung: The leading expert on Intermittent Fasting and insulin control.



Recommended Reading

The Real Meal Revolution by Tim Noakes
The Obesity Code by Dr.¬†Jason Fung
Primal Endurance by Mark Sisson

title: Born to Run
text:
Book: Born to Run by Christopher McDougall
Difficulty: Easy Jog (Extremely Readable)
The Gist: High-octane adventure meets evolutionary biology.






TipTL;DR Verdict



Essential reading. It reframes running from a chore into a biological necessity and a joy. Warning: Do not read this and immediately throw away your shoes; transition slowly.





Christopher McDougall was a broken runner. At 6‚Äô4‚Äù and 230 pounds, every doctor told him the same thing: ‚ÄúThe human body isn‚Äôt designed for running; stop before you destroy your knees.‚Äù
Refusing to accept that humans are destined to break, he trekked into the deadly Copper Canyons of Mexico to find the Tarahumara (the Rar√°muri), a reclusive tribe who run hundreds of miles at a time without injury, without rest, and‚Äîmost maddeningly of all‚Äîwith a smile on their faces.
This isn‚Äôt just a story about a race; it is a forensic investigation into why modern runners get hurt while ancient runners are still logging ultra-marathons in their 80s.




I‚Äôve broken the book down into three non-negotiable pillars.


McDougall argues that the modern Western runner is fueled by stress, calorie-counting, and ‚Äúno pain, no gain‚Äù suffering. The Tarahumara are fueled by korima (a culture of sharing) and pure joy.

The Lesson: Tension causes inefficiency. If you treat running like a chore or a battle, your muscles tighten, your form breaks, and you get injured. The Tarahumara run loose and laugh because relaxation = endurance.




This is the scientific backbone of the book. Referencing Harvard biologist Daniel Lieberman, McDougall argues that humans are the ultimate endurance machine. We aren‚Äôt fast, but we are the only animal that can shed heat while moving (sweating) and breathe independently of our stride.
The Data: We didn‚Äôt evolve to run to get away from predators; we evolved to run after prey until they collapsed from heat exhaustion. You were quite literally ‚Äúborn to run.‚Äù



The most controversial ‚Äúsplit‚Äù in the book. McDougall wages war on the modern running shoe industry, arguing that cushioned heels encourage a high-impact ‚Äúheel strike‚Äù that sends shockwaves through the joints.

He suggests that adding cushioning to a shoe is like putting a cast on a healthy limb‚Äîit causes the foot muscles to atrophy.






You don‚Äôt need to move to the Copper Canyons to run like a Tarahumara. Here is how to apply the book to your training tomorrow:






NoteüèÉ Practical Application




The ‚ÄúEasy, Light, Smooth‚Äù Mantra Caballo Blanco (the book‚Äôs mysterious coach figure) offers the ultimate form cue. Do not try to be fast.

First, focus on being Easy (relaxed).
Next, focus on being Light (quiet feet).
Then, focus on being Smooth.
Fast happens on its own as a result of the first three.

Cadence is King McDougall emphasizes a quick turnover (~180 steps per minute). This prevents over-striding (landing with your foot too far in front of you), which is the primary cause of knee, hip, and shin injuries.
Fuel Like a Minimalist The characters survive on Pinole (toasted corn flour) and Chia seeds (the ‚Äúrunner‚Äôs caviar‚Äù). The lesson is to focus on whole, simple foods rather than processed gels that spike and crash your blood sugar.







Is it a PR or a DNF?
Verdict: PR (Personal Record)
This book launched the ‚Äúbarefoot running‚Äù craze of 2010. While that led to some injuries for the unprepared, the core message remains untouched. Read it for the spirit. It successfully reframes running from a ‚Äúpunishment for eating pizza‚Äù into a celebration of human history. If you take nothing else away from this book take away that humans have evolved to move and the closer to we stick the our origins the better things are likely to work out in the long run.
Final Score: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

title: Run Elite
text:
Book: Run Elite by Andrew Snow Difficulty: Moderate (An attempt to cover everything) The Gist: A book that aims to be a comprehensive manual covering training, mindset, and nutrition.






CautionTL;DR Verdict



Score: 6/10 (Would be higher without the nutrition section). It tries to be a ‚ÄúJack of all trades‚Äù but ends up being a master of none. It offers a great introduction to various concepts, but if you want deep expertise, you might be left hungry.





It is notoriously hard to review general training books because they walk a fine line between ‚Äútoo simple‚Äù and ‚Äútoo complex.‚Äù Andrew Snow attempts to bridge the gap by offering a holistic system.
The book shines brightest in its opening chapters. Snow dives deep into the psychology of performance, referencing the approaches of legends like Emil Z√°topek, Roger Bannister, Eliud Kipchoge, Steve Prefontaine, and Usain Bolt. It sets a strong stage, suggesting that before you train the legs, you must train the governor in the brain.






This is where the book delivers real value. The sections on mental resilience are actionable and engaging. * It serves as a solid gateway drug to dedicated mental training. * Reviewer Note: If this section hooks you, you are better off graduating immediately to specialized texts like The Confident Mind or Beyond Grit for the deep dive.



Snow advocates for a specific type of speed work that many endurance runners neglect: Alactic Hill Sprints. * The logic is to recruit maximum muscle fibers without flooding the legs with lactate. It‚Äôs about neural drive, not metabolic conditioning.



This is where the book loses momentum. The nutritional advice feels less rigorous than the training philosophy. * Critique: The nutrition section feels like ‚Äújunk miles.‚Äù It distracts from the core message. If you want evidence-based nutrition or metabolic efficiency, you are better off waiting for the new Lore of Running or looking up Tim Noakes‚Äô recent work.



While the book covers base training, speed work, and tapering, the actual plans lack the specificity and inspiration found in the gold standards. * Alternative: If you want a plan that is battle-tested, go to Jack Daniels (for precision) or Pfitzinger‚Äôs Advanced Marathoning (for volume).





Despite the critiques, there are three diamonds in the rough that I have incorporated into my own training:






NoteüèÉ Practical Application




Taper Less Snow argues that many amateur runners treat the taper like a vacation. They shut down too early, losing muscle tension and ‚Äúpop.‚Äù The takeaway: Keep the intensity high, just drop the volume. Don‚Äôt let your engine go cold.
Work More on Mindset Physical fitness is often capped by mental fragility. Snow reinforces that you need to intentionally train your ability to suffer and stay calm, just like you train your VO2 Max.
The 8-Second Hill Rep This is a specific, actionable workout.

The Drill: Run up a steep hill at max effort for only 8 seconds.
The Recovery: Full recovery (wait until you are breathing normally).
The Why: This builds explosive power and running economy without the fatigue of a 400m repeat. It creates a ‚Äúspringier‚Äù runner.








Is it a PR or a DNF?
Verdict: A Solid Tempo Run (But not a Race Winner)
Run Elite is well worth a read‚Äîespecially if you can find it second-hand. It offers some unique training advice (like the hill reps) that you won‚Äôt hear elsewhere. However, it suffers from trying to do too much. It offers an appetizer for every aspect of running but doesn‚Äôt quite serve the main course.
Final Recommendations: * For Mindset: Switch to The Confident Mind. * For Plans: Switch to Faster Road Racing (Pfitzinger). * For Nutrition: Switch to Tim Noakes. * For Run Elite: Read the first half, steal the hill sprints, and skim the rest.

title: Strength Training
text: Strength training is non-negotiable for runners. It boosts economy, increases fatigue resistance, and keeps you injury-free.

title: Strength Training
text:
The Routine
You don‚Äôt need a gym membership. A simple bodyweight routine performed consistently is better than a complex heavy-lifting routine performed sporadically.






NoteCore Exercises




Squat Jumps

Why: Boosts explosive power.
Tip: Keep chest up; extend hips completely.

Bulgarian Split Squat

Why: Fixes imbalances; generates single-leg stability.
Tip: Don‚Äôt let your front knee collapse inward.

Single Leg Squat (Pistol Prep)

Why: Ultimate stability and core control.
Tip: Use a chair for balance initially.

Glute Bridge

Why: Wakes up the posterior chain (often asleep in runners).
Tip: Drive through your heels.

title: Strength Training
text:
Upper Body & Core
Running is a full-body movement. Your arms drive your legs.

Push Ups: Strengthens core and chest for driving power.
Plank / Side Plank: Promotes core stability to hold form when tired.
Bent Over Row: Strengthens back for postural endurance on long runs.


Guideline: Aim for 2 sessions per week. Keep it simple, keep it consistent.
